prior_works.title: A Three-Way Model for Collective Learning on Multi-Relational Data (RESCAL)
prior_works.authors: Maximilian Nickel, Volker Tresp, Hans-Peter Kriegel
prior_works.relationship_sentence: RESCAL’s bilinear tensor factorization score is one of the core KGE functions the paper recasts as a circuit/energy, forming a primary target for conversion into a tractable generative circuit model.

prior_works.title: Complex Embeddings for Simple Link Prediction (ComplEx)
prior_works.authors: Théo Trouillon, Johannes Welbl, Sebastian Riedel, Éric Gaussier, Guillaume Bouchard
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ComplEx’s complex-valued bilinear scoring form is explicitly reinterpreted as a circuit, and its energy-based view motivates the paper’s recipes (non-negativity/squaring) to obtain normalized generative PCs with exact MLE and sampling.

prior_works.title: TuckER: Tensor Factorization for Knowledge Graph Completion
prior_works.authors: Ivana Balažević, Carl Allen, Timothy M. Hospedales
prior_works.relationship_sentence: TuckER’s Tucker-decomposition scoring is another key target whose multilinear form the authors map into circuit structure, showing how a standard KGE becomes a tractable generative model under circuit constraints.

prior_works.title: Canonical Tensor Decomposition for Knowledge Base Completion (CP/N3)
prior_works.authors: Timothée Lacroix, Nicolas Usunier, Gabriel Obozinski
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The CP decomposition applied to KGs provides a canonical multilinear score that the paper casts as a circuit and then regularizes via non-negativity or squaring to yield a generative, tractable probabilistic model.

prior_works.title: A Differential Approach to Inference in Bayesian Networks (Arithmetic Circuits)
prior_works.role: Foundational circuits for tractable inference and exact MLE
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Arithmetic circuits established decomposable/smooth computation enabling exact marginalization and gradient-based learning, the core tractability properties the paper leverages when converting KGE scores into circuit-based generative models.

prior_works.title: Sum-Product Networks: A New Deep Architecture
prior_works.role: Probabilistic circuits enabling tractable generative modeling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SPNs introduced non-negativity and structural constraints (decomposability/smoothness) that guarantee normalized densities and efficient sampling—principles echoed by the paper’s non-negativity and squaring recipes for KGE-to-PC conversion.

prior_works.title: Probabilistic Sentential Decision Diagrams
prior_works.authors: Alper Kisa, Guy Van den Broeck, Arthur Choi, Adnan Darwiche
prior_works.role: Circuit family for enforcing logical constraints
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PSDDs showed how logical constraints can be encoded by circuit structure while preserving tractability, directly informing the paper’s claim that circuitized KGEs can satisfy logical constraints by design.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core move is to reinterpret leading KGE score functions as tractable probabilistic circuits, then enforce simple constraints (non-negativity or squaring) to convert them into normalized generative models that permit exact maximum-likelihood learning, efficient sampling, and built-in logical constraints. This synthesis stands on two pillars. First, multilinear/tensor KGE formulations—RESCAL, ComplEx, TuckER, and CP/N3—provide the precise algebraic score forms to be recast as circuit computations. These models’ bilinear or Tucker/CP factorization structures map naturally onto circuit graphs where sums and products reflect mixture and factorization over entities and relations. Second, the tractable inference literature on circuits—arithmetic circuits and sum-product networks—supplies the key structural conditions (decomposability, smoothness) and parameter constraints (notably non-negativity) that guarantee exact marginalization and normalized densities, enabling exact MLE and sampling. The PSDD line further demonstrates how logical constraints can be embedded into the circuit’s support while retaining tractability, which the authors exploit to ensure constraint satisfaction by design. By marrying the expressiveness and empirical strength of standard KGEs with the provable tractability of probabilistic circuits, the paper provides a principled path from discriminative KGE scoring to fully generative, scalable models for knowledge graphs without sacrificing link prediction performance.
